title: Exploiting aCropalypse: Recovering Truncated PNGs | Blog

last_post.content:
This one, dubbed 'aCropalypse', is also a bit heinous. Screenshots cropped on Pixel phones using the de facto tool store the cropped part within the image itself, and this omitted part can later be un-cropped/recovered. The result is countless screenshots out in the wild with potentially sensitive info not intended to be shared.

Easy read version:

https://www.techtimes.com/articles/289229/20230319/google-pixel-acropalypse-exploit-s-markup-tool-uncrop-photos-reveal.htm

And an excellent technical writeup for fellow #infosec peeps:

https://www.da.vidbuchanan.co.uk/blog/exploiting-acropalypse.html

I know AI isn't sentient but I cannot get over the fact that in OpenAI's red team exercise GPT-4 needed to work around a captcha so it hired a TaskRabbit. When the TaskRabbit questioned if GPT-4 was a robot GPT-4 lied and said it needed help because they were visually impaired.

This is just what OpenAI found, we should be very worried about what they don't find. And this information isn't conspiracy theory or secret, it’s readily available in OpenAI's GPT-4 System Card. https://cdn.openai.com/papers/gpt-4-system-card.pdf

title: Copyright and Artificial Intelligence | U.S. Copyright Office

last_post.content: The Copyright Office has launched an initiative to examine the copyright law and policy issues raised by artificial intelligence (AI) technology, including the scope of copyright in works generated using AI tools and the use of copyrighted materials in AI training. After convening public listening sessions in the first half of 2023 to gather information about current technologies and their impact, the Office will publish a notice of inquiry in the Federal Register. https://copyright.gov/ai/?loclr=eanco

Why did the United States invade Iraq in 2003? It's incredible — in the literal sense of the term — but 20 years later we don't really know. All that news coverge, all the books, and still the reasons are opaque.

Times journalist Max Fisher suggests an answer. Many, many people in the Bush orbit wanted a war against Saddam, but for different reasons. So they settled on WMDs as a kind of common coin. From there momentum grew and grew.

#uspol

title: Citing staffing issues and political climate, North Idaho hospital will no longer deliver babies - Idaho Capital Sun

last_post.content:
Idaho has one of the most restrictive abortion laws in the US. This has set off a Rube Goldberg machine that kills women and their babies.

A Sandpoint hospital that serves 8,000 will no longer deliver babies or provide OB/GYN or pediatric care, citing legislation that criminalizes MDs for providing medical care.

OB/GYNs and pediatricians are fleeing the state in droves, leaving women without medical care.

In addition, the Idaho legislature did not renew the Maternal Mortality Review Committee that investigates and reports on deaths among pregnant women and new mothers.

They are killing us and they don't care. It's not about the babies. It's about controlling us and putting our health in jeopardy.

#uspol #uspolitics #bansoffourbodies #abortionrights #womenshealth #healthcare #healthcareisahumanright #idaho #idaholeg #fuckidaho
https://idahocapitalsun.com/2023/03/17/citing-staffing-issues-and-political-climate-north-idaho-hospital-will-no-longer-deliver-babies/

title: ChatGPT can’t access the internet, even though it really looks like it can

last_post.content:
I see people being deceived by this again and again: ChatGPT can NOT read content from URLs that you give it, but it will pretend that it can (and can be incredibly convincing when it does that)

Constantly debunking this feels like a Sisyphean task, but it's really important to spread this message any time you see anyone falling into this (very understandable) trap

https://simonwillison.net/2023/Mar/10/chatgpt-internet-access/

title: Ethics of Decentralized Social Technologies: Lessons from the Web3 Wave

last_post.content:
I highly recommend the recent 'Ethics of Decentralized Social Technologies' white paper: https://gettingplurality.org/2023/03/18/ethics-of-decentralized-social-technologies-lessons-from-the-web3-wave/.

One in a series of papers from the GETTING-Plurality Research Network. I'm taken by their broad approach, balancing political economy & philosophy with solid socio-technical analysis.

This paper touches on the opportunities and dangers presented by the convergence of Web3 and generative AI. LLMs aren't the only game in town.

#sts #philosophy #digitalhumanities #fedeverse

title: Maybe Zoom Parties Weren’t So Bad - Clive Thompson - Medium

last_post.content:
"Maybe Zoom Parties Weren't So Bad"

In which I look at some early -- and thus still very provisional -- research suggesting that all those video hangouts were good for our mental health during the early pandemic, and might even continue to be good now

Partially inspired by @TedUnderwood 's toot https://sigmoid.social/@TedUnderwood/110044685578705752 I'm curious how much everyone is starting to pay for AI "tools"? It seems like the SaaS-ification of research infrastructure is accelerating, but haven't heard of libraries or universities buying access to something like ChatGPT-4 so assuming everyone is just eating the cost directly and wondering what that looks like.

In full disclosure, I currently pay for Google Colab, Github Copilot, and Notion AI for a total of $30/per month. I'll probably drop Notion AI but the other two have been helpful for times when I need GPU access and when I have formulaic code to write. Considering paying for ChatGPT Plus access but that's another $20 and starting to wonder where this ends 👀

So if you feel comfortable sharing fill out this very unscientific poll please 🙏🏽 #AI #DH #DigitalHumanities

1. #PyQGIS 101: Introduction to #QGIS #Python #programming for non-programmers
http://anitagraser.com/pyqgis-101-introduction-to-qgis-python-programming-for-non-programmers/

:qgis: ❤️ :python:

I'm very happy to see how popular this mini series has become

#GISChat

Here's a short demo/discussion of some of the new features in #QGIS 3.30 's-Hertogenbosch
I am so excited to see the native Raster Attribute Table (RAT) support!

title: John Deere's ongoing GPL violations: What's next

last_post.content:
Update. Turns out that John #Deere has been using open code under the #GPL w/o living up to the license. The Software Freedom Conservancy (@conservancy) is calling on it to comply — which would greatly enhance #farmers' #RightToRepair.
https://sfconservancy.org/blog/2023/mar/16/john-deere-gpl-violations/

"We…publicly call on John Deere to immediately resolve all of its outstanding GPL violations…by providing complete source code…that the GPL & other copyleft licenses require, to the farmers & others who are entitled to it."

#OpenSource

title: Four Souls of Coyote — Official Teaser

last_post.content:
A Hungarian animation studio just created a big screen full-length animated movie titled The Four Souls of Coyote. It's a story based on various Native American mythologies. It came out both in Hungarian and in English.

Does anyone know if #indigenous reviewers have seen this? Over here in Hungary none of the media outlets mention if anyone wrote anything about it from a cultural perspective. And it bugs me...

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IJSCGjQ366A

#animation #film

title: The Model That Changes Everything: Alpaca Breakthrough (ft. Apple's LLM, BritGPT, Ernie and AlexaTM)

last_post.content:
Stanford has created an AI model called Stanford Alpaca.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xslW5sQOkC8

It's capable of doing what ChatGPT does and more, except at a fraction of the cost: $600. They were allowed to do this because Alpaca didn't have to be trained same as GPT was, it only had to learn all of GPT's tricks watching GPT play.

Microsoft placed a $2 billion bet on OpenAI, so that makes them look $2 billion less smart than last week.
https://the-decoder.com/stanfords-alpaca-shows-that-openai-may-have-a-problem/

#OpenAI #AGI #gpt #chatgpt #StanfordAlpaca
